title: This is how poisonous green crisps are - and why you still find one them in your packet
text:
Food Unwrapped's Matt Tebbutt looked into why some crisps end up green Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
In the same way there's a rogue, chewy Malteser in nearly every bag, most packets of crisps contain a green one. 
As kids, with it's endless poisonous potential, the green crisp was something to be feared. 
Nestled among all the other tasty crisps, the green crisp is unnerving. 
Just why is it so green? Can they do me any harm if I ingest it? Will it taste as disgusting as I suspect it does? 
Green potato crisps have now become the subject of Channel 4 show, Food Unwrapped , and there are answers to all the above. What causes some crisps to turn green? 
You'll be relieved to hear that it's not something unduly worrying or dangerous. Matt visited potato farmers to get some answers 
Co-presenter Matt Tebbutt visited a Norfolk farm to get an explanation - and it's pretty simple. 
Potatoes grow underground and are therefore shielded from sunlight. However, if parts of them start to grow above the ground, they then are exposed to light and will start to change colour. Read More 
That's what accounts for the green hue - it's simply chlorophyll, a pigment which is intensified by light. Are the green crisps safe to eat? 
Well, not entirely. 
Chlorophyll can contain a chemical for solanine, which is the same toxin produced by deadly nightshade. The crisps are examined 
However, those playground fears about the a green crisp's noxious qualities may not be fully justified. 
Matt talks to a farmer who points out if you eat a lot of green crisps, then no, you won't feel very well. Read More 
To put this into perspective, Matt then adds that despite the toxin being poisonous you would have to eat one large entirely green potato to become unwell. 
To be fair, we're probably still going to continue binning every green crisp we encounter. Like us on Facebook
